articles.headline: A Big Blast in North Korea, and Big Questions on U.S. Policy
articles.snippet: North Korea’s most powerful nuclear test yet shows that gradually escalating sanctions are not stopping it from becoming a nuclear state.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s most powerful nuclear test yet shows that gradually escalating sanctions are not stopping it from becoming a nuclear state.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — North Korea’s latest test of an atomic weapon leaves the United States with an uncomfortable choice: Stick with a policy of incremental sanctions that has clearly failed to stop the country’s nuclear advances, or pick among alternatives that range from the highly risky to the repugnant.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Choe Sang-Hun and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Reliably Red Ohio County Finds Both Trump and Clinton Hard to Stomach
articles.snippet: Many residents of Delaware County, which last voted for a Democratic president in 1916, simply cannot imagine voting for either candidate.
articles.abstract: Many residents of Delaware County, which last voted for a Democratic president in 1916, simply cannot imagine voting for either candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DELAWARE, Ohio — Donald J. Trump is not popular in this prospering county north of Columbus. The Republican nominee’s dystopian language does not resonate here. Signs that read “Now Hiring” outnumber “Trump” campaign placards.

articles.headline: U.S. Suspends Construction on Part of North Dakota Pipeline
articles.snippet: The order came after a federal judge’s ruling rejected efforts by the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe to halt construction of the Dakota Access pipeline.
articles.abstract: The order came after a federal judge’s ruling rejected efforts by the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe to halt construction of the Dakota Access pipeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: BISMARCK, N.D. — The federal government on Friday temporarily blocked construction on part of a North Dakota oil pipeline, an unusual intervention in a prairie battle that has drawn thousands of Native Americans and activists to camp and demonstrate.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Monsanto Whistle-Blower: $22 Million Richer, but Not Satisfied
articles.snippet: The former employee at the agribusiness company said he was still bothered that management was not held accountable for years of accounting violations.
articles.abstract: The former employee at the agribusiness company said he was still bothered that management was not held accountable for years of accounting violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Winning isn’t everything.

articles.headline: Russia and the United States Reach New Agreement on Syria Conflict
articles.snippet: If successful, the agreement would reduce the violence and lead to joint military operations to target Islamic militants in Syria.
articles.abstract: If successful, the agreement would reduce the violence and lead to joint military operations to target Islamic militants in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Russia and the United States agreed early Saturday on a new plan to reduce violence in the Syrian conflict that, if successful, could lead for the first time to joint military targeting by the two powers against Islamic jihadists in Syria.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Apple Is Said to Be Rethinking Strategy on Self-Driving Cars
articles.snippet: The company has closed parts of its self-driving car project and laid off dozens of employees, according to three people briefed on the subject.
articles.abstract: The company has closed parts of its self-driving car project and laid off dozens of employees, according to three people briefed on the subject.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is rethinking what it plans to do about self-driving cars, just as other big tech companies appear ready to plow ahead with competing efforts.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Offers Regrets, but Doesn’t Admit Misconduct
articles.snippet: The case reflects a trend in which regulators fine financial institutions and require changes, but not an admission of wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: The case reflects a trend in which regulators fine financial institutions and require changes, but not an admission of wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo was flowing with regrets on Friday, taking out ads in nearly a dozen newspapers saying the bank took “full responsibility” for creating sham bank accounts without its customers’ permission.

articles.headline: For Rudy Giuliani, Embrace of Donald Trump Puts Legacy at Risk
articles.snippet: A Trump victory could open the door for a return to public office for Mr. Giuliani. A loss, however, could be a last act for “America’s Mayor.”
articles.abstract: A Trump victory could open the door for a return to public office for Mr. Giuliani. A loss, however, could be a last act for “America’s Mayor.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, with bodies still being pulled from the smoldering rubble, New York’s mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, delivered an emotional address before a hushed United Nations.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Secret History of Colombia’s Paramilitaries and the U.S. War on Drugs
articles.snippet: After decades of atrocities, the warlords were finally being held to account. Then the Americans stepped in.
articles.abstract: After decades of atrocities, the warlords were finally being held to account. Then the Americans stepped in.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALABAZO, Colombia — Skinny but imposing with aviator glasses, a bushy mustache and a toothy smile, Julio Henríquez Santamaría was leading a community meeting in this sylvan hamlet when he was abducted by paramilitary thugs, thrown into the back of a Toyota pickup and disappeared forever on Feb. 4, 2001.

articles.headline: No Driver? Bring It On. How Pittsburgh Became Uber’s Testing Ground
articles.snippet: Uber’s experiment with autonomous vehicles is proceeding with the blessing of city officials, who have pretty much just stayed out of the way.
articles.abstract: Uber’s experiment with autonomous vehicles is proceeding with the blessing of city officials, who have pretty much just stayed out of the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Any day now, Uber will introduce  a fleet of self-driving cars in Pittsburgh, making this former steel town the world’s first city to let any passenger hail an autonomous vehicle.

articles.headline: Cast-Out Police Officers Are Often Hired in Other Cities
articles.snippet: An Oregon officer was barred from taking another police job after a charge involving a child. Three months later, he was a police chief in Kansas. Experts say it’s a widespread problem.
articles.abstract: An Oregon officer was barred from taking another police job after a charge involving a child. Three months later, he was a police chief in Kansas. Experts say it’s a widespread problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a police officer in a small Oregon town in 2004, Sean Sullivan was caught kissing a 10-year-old girl on the mouth.

articles.headline: Putin, Admired by Donald Trump, Emphasizes Strength as Virtue
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin shows skill at rallying the support of the Russian public no matter what the circumstances.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin shows skill at rallying the support of the Russian public no matter what the circumstances.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tiger shooter, bare-chested horseman and architect of Russia’s revival as a muscular global power, President Vladimir V. Putin, dressed in a somber suit and tie, sat for over an hour this past week sipping tea from a delicate porcelain cup and offering earnest advice on how to improve housing, medical care and other services in a provincial town south of here.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Doctor Says Pneumonia Led to Abrupt Exit From 9/11 Event
articles.snippet: The incident, which occurred after months of questions about Mrs. Clinton’s health from Republicans, is likely to increase pressure on her to address the issue.
articles.abstract: The incident, which occurred after months of questions about Mrs. Clinton’s health from Republicans, is likely to increase pressure on her to address the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is being treated for pneumonia and dehydration, her doctor said on Sunday, hours after she abruptly left a ceremony in New York honoring the 15th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks and had to be helped into a van by Secret Service agents.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Spate of Deadly Attacks in Syria Ahead of Cease-Fire
articles.snippet: At least 91 people have been killed in strikes on rebel-held areas in the two days since Russia and the United States declared that a cease-fire would begin on Monday.
articles.abstract: At least 91 people have been killed in strikes on rebel-held areas in the two days since Russia and the United States declared that a cease-fire would begin on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Bags of body parts. Three young siblings killed along with their mother. A pregnant woman lying dead under a fallen roof.

articles.headline: Ireland Doesn’t Want Apple’s Back Taxes, but the Irish Aren’t So Sure
articles.snippet: After six years of belt-tightening and tax increases, many Irish workers say their government’s reluctance to collect $14.5 billion from Apple is unfair.
articles.abstract: After six years of belt-tightening and tax increases, many Irish workers say their government’s reluctance to collect $14.5 billion from Apple is unfair.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORK, Ireland — When European officials ordered Ireland to collect a record $14.5 billion in back taxes from Apple, Kieran O’Connell drew up a wish list for spending the money.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Says Pending Tesla Updates Could Have Prevented Fatal Crash
articles.snippet: The upgrades to Tesla’s Autopilot system will require drivers to refrain from taking their hands off the wheel for long periods and will use radar to better identify potential obstacles in the road.
articles.abstract: The upgrades to Tesla’s Autopilot system will require drivers to refrain from taking their hands off the wheel for long periods and will use radar to better identify potential obstacles in the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors is readying improvements to its Autopilot technology that might have prevented an accident in May that took the life of an Ohio man, Tesla’s chief executive said on Sunday. The man was killed when his Model S car driving in Autopilot crashed into a tractor-trailer.

articles.headline: Amazon and Pandora to Gauge Music’s Value in the Internet Age
articles.snippet: The companies are planning to charge as little as $5 a month for new streaming music services, half the cost of the current pricing model.
articles.abstract: The companies are planning to charge as little as $5 a month for new streaming music services, half the cost of the current pricing model.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much are people willing to spend for streaming music?

articles.headline: A New Phase for World of Warcraft’s Lead Designer: His Own Start-Up
articles.snippet: Rob Pardo, a gaming idol, is taking his reputation, experience and some of his former colleagues to his newest venture, Bonfire Studios.
articles.abstract: Rob Pardo, a gaming idol, is taking his reputation, experience and some of his former colleagues to his newest venture, Bonfire Studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big video games, like movies, are usually created by squadrons of people, including dozens or hundreds of artists and developers.

articles.headline: After 11 Years, Case of A.I.G.’s Ex-Chief Is Going to Trial
articles.snippet: Maurice Greenberg, once head of American International Group, and the insurer’s former financial chief face civil charges over transactions in 2000-1.
articles.abstract: Maurice Greenberg, once head of American International Group, and the insurer’s former financial chief face civil charges over transactions in 2000-1.
articles.lead_paragraph: It will not be the trial of the century. It may just feel as if it has taken that long to get underway.

articles.headline: Marriage Falls in China, Transforming Finances and Families
articles.snippet: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
articles.abstract: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Liu Zhenfeng got married at 25. The usual trappings of family life followed — a daughter, a home, furniture, toys.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Zhang Tiantian

articles.headline: A Glorified Sidewalk, and the Path to Transform Atlanta
articles.snippet: The Atlanta BeltLine project, which would circle the city’s urban core with a biking and pedestrian loop, aims to rejuvenate an area known for suburban sprawl.
articles.abstract: The Atlanta BeltLine project, which would circle the city’s urban core with a biking and pedestrian loop, aims to rejuvenate an area known for suburban sprawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Could this traffic-clogged Southern city, long derided as the epitome of suburban sprawl, really be discovering its walkable, bike-friendly, density-embracing, streetcar-riding, human-scale soul?

articles.headline: In a Shift, U.S. Includes Families in Hostage Rescue Efforts
articles.snippet: After President Obama ordered a policy overhaul last year, communication with families has improved and more than 70 captives have been returned. But over a dozen are still being held.
articles.abstract: After President Obama ordered a policy overhaul last year, communication with families has improved and more than 70 captives have been returned. But over a dozen are still being held.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the United States became aware late last month of a video showing an American woman and a Canadian man pleading to be saved from their Taliban captors, the government did something it had not done well in the past.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Is Set Back by Decision to Keep Illness Secret
articles.snippet: Her campaign, responding to political pressure after it belatedly revealed that she had pneumonia, promised more details about her health and medical records this week.
articles.abstract: Her campaign, responding to political pressure after it belatedly revealed that she had pneumonia, promised more details about her health and medical records this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after receiving a diagnosis of pneumonia on Friday, Hillary Clinton decided to limit the information to her family members and close aides, certain that the illness was not a crucial issue for voters and that it might be twisted and exploited by her opponents, several advisers and allies said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Donald Trump Seizes Hillary Clinton’s Absence to Press His Case
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump scrambled to put his rival on the defensive, showing unusual restraint over her illness but denouncing her charge that many of his supporters were bigoted.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump scrambled to put his rival on the defensive, showing unusual restraint over her illness but denouncing her charge that many of his supporters were bigoted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump hurled himself into a new effort to reshape the presidential race on Monday, scrambling to allay voters’ concerns about his temperament and put Hillary Clinton on the defensive over her critical comments about many of Mr. Trump’s supporters.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman
